posts.com:
So I've got several suggestions for OP.
A. Increase the density of another kind of legume by using it as a flour. Chickpea flour is very, very cheap and the protien content is double that of wheat flour. Many of the more exotic bean flours rate even higher.
>Lupin beans can be ground into a flour, and this is widely used in parts of Europe and in Australia as an additive to wheat flour, enhancing the flavour and lending a rich, creamy colour to the resulting foods
There you go, try to buy it debittered as a flour. If it's not debittered it's poisonous however.
B. Find other cheap protien sources, as vegetable protien usually has an incomplete amino acid profile you should eat a wide variety of vegetable proteins anyway, don't just take the one with the highest nominal protein content.
C. In Ecuador, the lupin is often consumed as a ceviche-like street food known as "cevichochos".
So you can brine them yourself and make a range of salads.

Where do you live btw, it helps to know what's available ingredients wise

American opinions on food are worthless, as they have never became accustomed to eating decebt quality produce on a regular basis, so they can only remember tastes partially and need to categorize everything they eat because otherwise they cannot tellthe difference.
For example, all the talk about mexican vs chinese vs italian vs whatever, when you come to it all these cuisines have completely different ways of preparing different ingredients. French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Greek, Thai, Viet, etc all have a method of preparing a big pot of boiled meat and vegetables. It's mostly the same dish with different details. Yet americans cannot conceive that mexican food doesn't have shitty "cheese", that italian food doesn't have tomato sauce, that chinese food doesn't have wok fried stuff, that french food doesn't have butter, etc. Since americans mostly lack experience travelling to other countries and not eatin only at tourists traps, they think each country is the caricature they are exposed to when they go to shitty restaurants. Just like they think italians eat meatballs because it's there in italian restaurants and that chinese food is what they eat at those chain takeout places. The most adventurous of them just go to youtube and then they think youtibe is the faithful representation of another country, so in essence they are still ignorant but in a different way.
Obviously, living in the largest economy in the world provides little incentive to explore other economies, because of the fake sense that there can't be anything better out there.
And that is why I never take an american's opinion on food seriously. All those american youtube cooks are frauds, you just unfortunately don't know any better.

If you're using something like a cast iron on electric, it can hold those insanely high heats long enough to get a sear on anything. The reason they prefer gas is because of the total BTU is higher, so when you're doing orders you can sear off an order a lot quicker because it's always going to be at least as hot as it needs to be.

Electric will get hot enough if you give it enough time, and get hotter than gas but if you overwhelm the amount of heat stored in the pan, electric won't heat it up again fast enough.

I think a nice pan with a copper core like All-Clad on an electric coil is the easiest way to cook when you have to control temperature precisely. If you really need insane temps than use an ash oven.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who has used all 3:
Electric is the worst. Not in terms of being to make great food - it does fine - but in terms of everything else. Heat doesn't resize itself. Glasstop gets uneven with stains with use that makes surface contact worse overtime. Fire that goes on and off (non constant).
Gas is almost as bad. Cleaning alone is a bitch. You get a constant fire and you get to use round bottom pans (woks) but if anything breaks it's a pain in the ass.
Induction is the best. easy to clean, temperature doesn't fluctuate as much as electric, and the only flaw is that you still need a flat bottom pan. Unless you're one of the 3 guys who somehow found the high thermal conductivity of completely dry copper pans To be absolutely essential/need woks you can scratch and swivel against a gas bracket or you'll die, induction really feels like the future.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
heres a recipe I made for a friend for my lasagna.

I never used a written recipe and learned from watching someone else make it. They never used a written recipe either.

all amounts were pulled out of my ass based on a best guess for the recipe. because the amounts of many of the seasonings don't matter that much. The person I gave it to said it was the best lasagna they had ever had. they had no trouble making it and never questioned me on exact measurements.

2 lbs. sweet and/or hot Italian sausage
1 package Lasagna Noodles
1 Table spoon olive oil
2 16oz. cans diced or crushed stewed tomatoes
2 or 3 lbs. Mozzarella cheese
Italian seasoning
dried chopped parsley
2 or 3 pints ricotta cheese
2 or 3 eggs
1 white onion medium to large
6 to 8 medium size mushrooms
2 or 3 cloves fresh garlic

Mix the 2 or 3 eggs, 2 or 3 tablespoons parsley, and Ricotta cheese together.

Chop the Mushrooms.

Boil the noodles in a large saucepan with the oil, and 1 tsp. salt in the water,
cook until still tough. drain and refill pan with cold water to keep noodles from
sticking together.

Coarse chop the onion, smash and finely dice 1 or 2 cloves of garlic.
Remove the sausage casing, and break up the sausage in a frying pan.
Brown the sausage with 2/3 the onion and all the garlic, salt and pepper to taste.
Drain off the grease.

In a 2 quart sauce pan combine the Stewed tomatoes, 1 tsp. Italian seasoning, the rest of the onion, 1 crushed and finely chopped clove of garlic, the mushrooms, and the Sausage.
bring to boil and then simmer about 15 minutes.

Arrange in layers in a ungreased 9x13" pan: sauce, ricotta cheese, mozzarella, and pasta.
Top the last layer with a generous amount of mozzarella.
Bake at 350 for 20 to 25 minutes or until sauce bubbles and the cheese is slightly brown.

posts.com:
>>18819547
>I just eyeball it every time.
I understand that. I'm saying your written recipe doesn't fall into OP's complaint because you actually provided ranges of measurements for everything to help give a concept of proper ratios to the person following the recipe. You never say, "Put in the appropriate amount of cheese," for instance, and instead give an approximate amount of cheese which would be appropriate within a range, and you did the same thing for every seasoning as well. Your recipe is better written than one which just says things like "to taste."

>he can't season food without detailed exact instructions.
It's helpful for a recipe to impart baseline ratios and amounts to work with so you understand the intended outcome and aren't just winging it completely your first time through. The latter has a greater potential for user error and recipe failure or waste.

>>18801313
There are a couple inaccuracies here but that image is 95% correct. Jesus probably didn't believe he himself was the messiah. He believed the messiah was about to show up and he called this messiah the "son of man." Jesus was basically a doomsday nut, which there were a lot of in the holy land at that time because of mounting tensions between Jews and the Romans - this led to a lot of doomsday nuts who believed that God was about to overthrow the Romans and establish His Good Kingdom on earth, but they (the Jews) just had to wait a little longer (and suffer under the Romans). It also leaves out a couple important details like why Jesus was crucified (the answer is that someone, possibly Judas, told the Romans that Jesus was claiming behind closed doors to be the king of the Kingdom of Heaven, and the romans interpreted this as insurrectionist speech).

Okay I don't dispute the paedophilia of historical eras (even our current era desu) but the "27 on average" thing is honestly bullshit-- it's a result of how statistics work. Typically people didn't make it past age 5 as a result of infant mortality and disease, which meant that the average living age, when mapped out, was lower.

But on actual averages, people have lived into their sixties since the dawn of time. "Natural" deaths under 50 that weren't a result of disease were always considered shocking and there has never been an era of human history where dying under 30 was considered expected unless the deceased was already ill.

And the latter likely not with an open mind or even an honest curiosity.

I went through all of that and what I found was that I would do anything I could to avoid talking about what's in there because I didn't want to understand it. So I focused on criticisms often carefully thought out and crafted. Instead of taking in the context in agreement. As to your point, I cannot tell you if there's some sea beast capable of holding a man for three days in it's jaw. I can tell you that while God asks you to do your work in the day, and sober, you should also give strong wine to those who are dying or are with heavy hearts. Nothing here contradicts and if we spend time looking for signs and seasons we miss the point. At best in a universe where objective reality is nothing more than what our five senses can detect we still haven't discussed what the Bible is saying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First impression tea notes:
2020 Jinggu (200g)
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/936595693/2020-jinggu-200g

Parameters:
12.2g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Taste:
Green bean, a bit green teaish in character (despite having some reddish tinged leaves suggesting some oxidation).
Some of the more traditionally shengy tart apricot and pear flavors.
Moderate bitterness and astringency (I have not had green tea for awhile but again this tea feels like it has a bit of green tea character to it in the way it goes down).
Relatively straightforward but pleasant and easy to drink.

Conclusion:
Seems like a fairly priced daily drinker young sheng, especially if you like a bit of green tea character. Probably a decent cake for newcomers to young sheng as well. At 200g/$20 I don't have any substantial complaints. Though if you dislike green bean taste you may want to stay away.

>>18811155
The internet says it's a yellow tea, I would first try a similar yellow tea. Otherwise, yellow tea is closest to green tea, puerh is probably a poor fit.
https://yunnansourcing.com/products/certified-organic-yunnan-yellow-tea
Note that I haven't specifically tried this, I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well. Most people don't really drink yellow tea, I'd order this, potentially this and the bud only tea, and see where you're at. As a bonus, I'd probably throw in some chinese green tea as well.
Mandala tea also aparantly sells some, I also haven't (and probably wouldn't) tried this.
https://www.mandalatea.com/white-teas?category=Yellow+Tea

posts.com:

>https://yunnansourcing.com/products/certified-organic-yunnan-yellow-tea
I have actually had that tea a few years back. It is effectively a more lightly oxidized black tea. I recall it having kind of a nice orange marmalade and almond biscotti flavor but also that it could get quite bitter if over brewed (like a lot of black tea).

>>18811219
>I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well.
Besides price why? I did not have the pure bud version but I suspect it may be slightly better because the buds will highlight some of that teas lighter more floral elements better over the bitter "maltiness". I do do doubt it is twice as good though so it is not going to be as good of value.
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/yunnan-sourcing-brand-certified-organic-teas/products/certified-organic-emperors-yellow-yunnan-yellow-tea

You can generally get stronger sweeter tea from a bit more stem / leaf. Buds are "lighter" because they don't extract well, you do get more floral notes though. One bud one leaf should push you farther into honey territory.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
matcha ice cream:
2qt half & half
12 egg yolks
2 cup sugar or 1 cup erythritol 1 cup allulose (or xylitol) or 2 cup erythritol if eating within 48 hours
matcha (doesn't matter, the sugar and cream is gonna murder any subtleties of the leaf)
25 dollar walmart churn https://www.walmart.com/ip/Nostalgia-4-Quart-Electric-Ice-Cream-Maker-Blue/749542584
big boxes of salt

1. make matcha with the half & half. it honestly doesn't matter how much you make, i've used just fuck my shit up levels and it was perfectly fine. it just has to dissolve
2. put a metal bowl on the stove and dump everything in it. remember to break yolks. add pinch of salt. turn the heat to maximum and stir it
3. you can do this until either the sugar is fully dissolved or to official guideline which is like 150F to kill salmonella. use infrared thermometer and remember what temperature you turned the heat off at for next time
4. dump ice cream custard into ice cream maker cylinder and put it in the fridge for a few hours
5. make lots of ice sitting in the freezer the day before
6. put cylinder in bucket, put paddle in cylinder, put motor on, dump layer of ice, layer of salt till it's full and plug in
7. churn for about 20-30 min or until it fails to churn. if you used sugar or plain erythritol, it's ready to eat. if you used erythritol with alluose (or xylitol), it needs a day or two in the freezer to get firmer. the bottom is usually ready though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18819787
Higher fermentation, darker tastes, more mellow, more rounded out, if fermented properly they are ready to drink much sooner, don't benefit much from aging.
Lighter fermentation, more likely to be bitter, retains more of the teas original character, less rounded and smoothed out, the really lightly fermented stuff needs a pretty solid aging period before its ready to drink, but they haven't produced much like that since the early 2000s and further back.

>>18821774
water can emulsify oil if you choose to emulsify it, but in its natural state it will sit below the oil.

All cheeses will 'sweat' when they warm up, this is a side effect of the protein chains loosening as they warm, releasing previously trapped stores of butterfat.

What you're seeing when the American cheese is melted into a creamy goo is the added emulsifying agent (usually sodium citrate) turning the protein into an emulsifying goop -a key ingredient in American cheese.
This is why you can also use a single slice of American cheese to thicken a sauce or make a sauce creamier, and why velveeta makes things so disgustingly creamy

This is probably the best option for them, but they likely won't go for it. I don't know if I'd be able to convince them to drop $100 for a used grinder. I may just buy it for them and hope they'll use it.

My parents' coffee situation is weird and, I think, a little bit funny. When I was growing up, they would drink shitty pre-ground Yuban or whatever they'd buy in bulk at Costco. About fifteen years ago, I got a part time at Starbucks, and got them a free bag of a coffee they sell called Casi Cielo, a seasonal Guatemalan coffee they sell, and probably the best whole bean coffee Starbucks carries. They fell in love with it, and asked me to hoard my free bags of coffee and ship it to them, instead of flipping it on eBay as I usually did. I haven't worked at Starbucks in about a decade, but my dad will still go to the local stores and buy up their entire supply whenever it's available, and now it's all they drink and told me they can't really stand the shitty pre-ground supermarket stuff. If they run out of that coffee, they'll switch to tea. When I visited them yesterday, I offered to grind their coffee with my hand grinder, but my mom stopped me because she immediately knew it would make a huge difference to have fresh burr-ground coffee, and she sort of didn't want to know, because she knew the financial rabbit hole coffee snobbery can lead to. They're reluctant to try better beans or better grinders, or better brew methods because they don't want to "have to" start spending more money on their morning coffee.

They burn your coffee, no matter what kind you use.

They heat up the whole thing. Just because you pinpoint heat a bit of the plate that doesn't mean that heat isn't going to be distributed throughout all the liquid. Why do people wait so long for sauerkraut when kimchi only takes like 1 week at room temp? Are the ingredients that different that fermentation is slower or something?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18821017
Kraut goes through 3 seperate fermentations by different bacterial colonies. This takes 3 weeks, and produces the most bacterially diverse and complex tasting kraut.

Basically what happens is as one colony metabolizes the primary food in the kraut it starves itself and another colony comes in to consume the previous bacteria's metabolites.

Sort of like how yeast makes sugar into alcohol and when all the sugar runs out acetobacter will come in and turn the alcohol into vinegar.

>>18817346
You can put this to a test actually! Get a timer or stopwatch, a measuring cup and turn on your faucet for 15 seconds. Multiply the amount of water you've collected and you have your faucets output by mintute. Your dishwasher has a user manual that will tell you how many gallons or liters it uses per cycle, but if you don't trust this you can monitor your water meter and see for yourself! If it was manufactured after 2010, it likely uses somewhere between 2 and 4 gallons per cycle.

Now that you've established how much water you use per minute from your faucet, time yourself washing your dishes. With some simple math, you'll see if your feeling about water and energy use is correct or not (it won't be, by the way).

>>18819296
4 cups whole wheat flour
Pint of water
Yeast pack
Tablespoon honey
Teaspoon salt

Proofed yeast with honey in the warmed water, then mixed with the flour and salt (which I had sifted together). Kneaded it until it was plump and well incorporated
Let rise for an hour covered by a hot damp towel, rewarmed towel and placed dough in a bread tin and let it rise for another hour. Baked for 15 minutes at gas mark 7 (425F), then for another 40 minutes at gas mark 4 (350F).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820505
Hotdog stands in denmark, they are unlike any other hotdogs and it's so difficult to place, I've tried so many dog types and sausages but they're not the same. they also have pickled cucumbers that aren't like regular pickles. there was this remolade yellow sauce that tasted like a really refined big mac sauce. I ate so many of them when I visited and they had stands literally everywhere. It's almost scary how common they are. Stayed a couple nights on the coast in a really rural part. it had like one store for groceries within 20 miles and no other commerce aside from farms. Even in that remote old people place there was still a god damn hot dog trailer that would park outside the grocery every day. I swear you could go hiking in the forest, go off the beaten trail, fall into a ravine and find a hotdog stand at the bottom of it. Only visited once though, so maybe I just had crazy luck.
it's unique because I've never called a hotdog "refreshing" but that's the best way I could describe it.

>>18818126
>how do i zazz up my mac and cheese?
Well, Annies always tastes like cardboard box it was shipped in, so start with not buying it ever again. I have found the store brands are always better than than that crap. For instance, Publix brand is better than Kraft and doesn't have the MSG-ish additves.

But, if you really want to upgrade your craft without a bechamel step, then go for the back of the box recipe with Barilla. Cook your less flimsy nice pasta noodles in the milk itself, with a diced onion. Shred in your real aged cheddar, letting the pasta sauce be thickening with the natural starch in the milk cooking liquid. A little pinch of cayenne can sharpen up the cheese funk, or pinch of white pepper or mustard powder, alternately.
Top your quick mac n cheese with crisply toasted seasoned fresh breadcrumbs or panko. I like a bit of parm in crumbs. Their crunch adds some texture.

posts.com:
>>18819726
Right after the unification of Italy a guy called Pellegrino Artusi travelled the country and wrote the first Italian cookbook. It's from 1891, not even 150 years ago.

He's the first to describe a ragu (from French ragout) in the fashion of Bologna. He advises against using tomatoes, "as they stick their nose into everything they shouldn't, just like priests do" (they were a huge fad at the time). But he does allow milk and fresh porcini.

Bolognese sauce only became popular in the 1960s and only in the US, and by that time it had become unrecognizable (poor illiterate migrants like Marcella Hazan and war vets didnn't know how to cook).

Since this is our first /ssg/ lets start off with a little history.

It has been estimated that as much as two-thirds of deceased soldiers in the US Civile War were killed not by bullets but by disease, with the most prevalent of those diseases being the intestinal illnesses diarrhea and dysentery. It was not clear, based on the established medical knowledge, exactly what caused these illnesses to flourish in military camps, but one physician by the name of James H. Salisbury suspected diet was the greatest culprit, and came up with his own solution.

He believed vegetables and starchy foods produced poisonous substances in the digestive system which were responsible for heart disease, tumors, mental illness and tuberculosis. He believed that human dentition demonstrated that humans were meant to eat meat, and sought to limit vegetables, fruit, starches, and fats to one-third of the diet.

The Salisbury steak, his means of achieving this goal, is ground beef flavored with onion and seasoning and then deep-fried or boiled and covered with gravy or brown sauce. It was introduced in 1888. Salisbury saw beef as an excellent defense against many different physical problems. He suggested that Salisbury steak should be eaten three times a day, with much hot water to cleanse the digestive system. He was an early American proponent of a low-carbohydrate diet for weight loss, and he promoted his diet for that purpose. His diet became known as the "Salisbury diet".

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18817680
My rye bread keeps at least one month in the fridge. It's made with rye sourdough and 10% wheat flour to make it stick together well. 70% boiled whole rye grain. No doubt the sourdough makes it keeps way longer, like over double time, stays flavourfull because the whole grains. The best way to make it keep well is to let a bit of fresh air dry it slowly if possible, that's true for all bread, but most importantly let it stay half a day to dry and steam off completely.
Making it keep well by drying it slowly is true for almost all store brought bread as well, but depending on how much taste the wheat loses when drying, like toast becomes almost instantly dull when dried compared to toasted, you'll need to decide when mould normally hits. Rye is a bit different.

Four Loko is illegal because it contains both alcohol and caffeine, which when combined can lead to a state of wide-awake drunk, where a person may feel alert and able to drive or make other poor decisions while still under the influence of alcohol. On the other hand, Irish coffee is legal because it contains only alcohol and caffeine from coffee, and not in a combination that would create a dangerous state. The amount of caffeine in Irish coffee is generally lower than the amount found in energy drinks and it is not mixed with other stimulants.
Additionally, Irish coffee is typically consumed in a more controlled setting, such as a bar or restaurant, where a person is less likely to engage in risky behavior, while energy drinks like Four Loko are often consumed in a party or social setting where excessive drinking is more likely to occur.

>>18821352
>Wtf is bad cork?
Waaaay back in the day, wine could go bad. So there was this little ritual where the waiter would let you smell the cork, then taste the wine to make sure it didn't go bad. This as before sanitation was fully understood. In 2023 you'll never find a spoiled bottle of wine. But some people insist on the ritual.

The real WTF is that OP did this by himself, without the waiter at the table. If it's not the waiter doing it, then you're not in a resto where the wine ritual is appropriate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18821135
aw shit i came here to say this! i'll expand briefly--there are several things i like about this cookbook. first off is that everything in it will minimally be good. the recipes are all trustworthy, even if they won't be like your favorite version of something. but with lots of cookbooks you cook something and maybe you don't like it and you're like, does this recipe suck or did i fuck it up? also, and relatedly, the thing i really really like about america's test kitchen recipes is that they explain what their preferred result is. so they'll start a recipe with, 'we like our food xx to be like this and this, and we set out to figure out how to do it.' so you know what THEIR version of good is for a given recipe, which helps you to both decide if you want to make that recipe and, again, makes it possible to see if you you did it right, since they've explained what the results should be like.

posts.com: I'm currently buried in sleeping /k/itties, but I made lentils last night. Cut four rashers of thick cut bacon into bite sized pieces, browned them in the pot to retain delicious fat, removed from heat, added seasonings (Bay leaves, celery seed, copious thyme, a little fresh black pepper, a little crushed red pepper, just a touch of sea salt) and aromatics, specifically some yellow onion and half a dozen whole cloves of garlic. Then went the lentils themselves, then the water, and then it was back onto the stove to simmer for about an hour or so. I'm pretty pleased with the results, and my brother seemed to like it well enough.

>>18817354
Dressing balances and seasons the vegetables. A big bowl of salad for 4 people only needs at most half a cup of good dressing.

Here is my favorite recipe:
4tbs evoo
1tbs dijon mustard
1tbs of good white wine vinegar
.5-1 clove of minced garlic
S&P

Mix everything except oil. Slowly drizzle evoo into mix until emulsified. Add 2 tsp of water to thin.

Healthy, simple, light dressing that seasons everything and brightens up the greens while not over powering any of the other flavors.

posts.com: Hey /ck/. I've made many gallons of Apple and pear cider as well as ginger beer and other fermented beverages but I've never made wine before. I started a few days(jan 13) ago with some cold pressed orange strawberry juice from whole foods and added amalayse and ec-1118. Half gallon of juice and .4g of yeast. Pitched the yeast and added it to the container with the airlock and it's been going great. Fermenting very vigorously. Yesterday I was at the store and found Welches simply peach juice blend drink on sale for $2.50 per 52 oz and I couldn't pass up the opportunity to give it a try. Check the label and it did not contain any absorbic acid or anything that would prevent fermentation to my knowledge. I added the same amylase enzyme, ec 1118 wine yeast and a small amount of vanilla paste and honey to 64 oz of the peach drink and it's been going for about 30 hours now but instead of vigorous fermentation with a lot of bubbles the only change that I've noticed is a moderate amount of sediment collecting at the top of the fermentation vessel. I know what krausen is and I don't think that's what this is, I didn't use an ale yeast. Does anyone with wine making experience know if this is okay or what it is? What could be keeping it from fermenting as vigorously as the other juice? Any information or suggestions related or not would be greatly appreciated

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: yeah

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It sounds like you have made a start at making a peach wine. The fact that your peach juice is not fermenting as vigorously as your orange-strawberry juice is likely due to differences in the juice itself, such as the sugar content or the presence of other microorganisms that are inhibiting the growth of your wine yeast.
It's also possible that the juice was pasteurized, which can affect the ability of the yeast to ferment.
It's also possible that the yeast was not as healthy or was not pitched in the right quantity.
It's generally a good idea to check the specific gravity of your juice before and after fermentation to get an idea of how much sugar is being converted to alcohol.
It's also important to monitor the temperature of the fermentation, as the yeast can ferment best within a specific range (usually between 60-80°F).
If you are worried and want to be sure, you can try to take a sample of your peach juice and test the pH and the sugar content.
Please keep in mind that the process of wine making can be unpredictable and fermentation can take a long time. So don't worry too much about the initial lack of vigorous fermentation.

>>18820384
>Does anyone with wine making experience know if this is okay or what it is?
Its normal. Sometimes the trub sinks, sometimes it rises. Don't shake the container, but pick it up with a limp wrist and rotate it left and right (the bottle stays upright, you just spin it like a centrifuge slightly)
>What could be keeping it from fermenting as vigorously as the other juice?
What was the gravity before you pitched the yeast? What is the gravity now?
30 hours of "vigorous fermentation" but you only added some honey...
>EC-1118
Good overall yeast thats pretty hardy, I've fermented to 17.5% alcohol with it before (of course requires lots of sugar). For your peach wine, it could have converted all the sugar already. Invest in a hydrometer if you don't have one already, they are cheap

So I've had people rant and rave at me for ages about how amazing rice cookers are
Me, I'm just a regular idiot who cooks rice on a stovetop. The directions say, equal parts water, cook 15 minutes, don't take the lid off. So that's what I do and the rice is cooked and perfect in 15 minutes.

Then I got a rice cooker for christmas, I'd always wanted one, I was pretty excited.

And you know what? It's fucking crap. It cooks rice fine but what takes me 15 minutes on a stovetop takes 50!!! minutes in a rice cooker. The rice that comes out is otherwise identical, and the rice cooker takes like 3 minutes longer to clean than my pot does. because it's got more parts. I've clearly missed something here because this is not easier and more convenient for rice cooking, it takes the exact same amount of effort as cooking on stovetop but 4x longer to cook and a little more effort to clean.

So why the hell do people buy these things instead of just cooking on the stove? Is it really so fucking hard to just not lift the lid to stir the rice for 99% of the population or something???

>>18813813
It depends on the type of rice down to the specific cultivar really, but great rice is when you coax the most flavor and desirable texture out of your rice.

If you cook rice exactly the same every time you are not good at cooking rice. As rice ages, and the variance from bag to bag it needs adjustment in the cooking process, mainly more or less water.

If you aren't critically assessing the rice you mads, and thinking of how you can try to improve it the majority of the time you aren't even on the path of achieving great rice. You're merely using it as an easy filler food.

Rice is easy to cook, difficult to perfect.

>>18813772
Rice cookers are convenient because they hold the rice at a warm temperature after they are done and you literally can't fuck it up unless you mismeasure. It's one task that no longer requires your attention at all(whereas stovetop rice requires you to at least be minimally aware and can be burnt). Many people are very anxious in the kitchen, so they overvalue the idiot-proof nature of the rice cooker.

That being said, if you eat rice every day they are great. A good rice cooker can not only cook perfect rice without effort, it can also hot hold it all day, and reheat leftover rice perfectly.

Personally, I mostly eat Basmati rice at home, so I just boil it like pasta if I want plain rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813853
>>18814657
No, the previous anon is 100% correct. I cook over 90 litres of sushi rice a week and the amount of water required to get the correct consistency varies from an even 1/1 ratio to 1/1.25 depending on the crop. As we get later in the season it gets drier and drier. Me and the sushi chef taste every single batch. It needs to have a specific firmness, and the release of starch also needs to be controlled so it's slightly sticky, meaning that I also vary the amount of rice conditioner and the time I spend rinsing it. The quality of the rice also varies along what proportion of the rice grains are broken; with higher proportions from lower quality crops(like the most recent Calrose crop) requiring additional rinsing as the broken grains release more starch,

>>18820882
Here you go:

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.


I THINK that the uneven flame/heat creates "heat turbulence" along with the specific shape of the pot. I haven't actually researched it all that much, so if anyone knows any better chime in please.

>>18813702
>having to pay your interns
This is baffling to me. The economics are just very strange. For example, many young people looking to further their academic careers but failed to get into a paid PhD program would be willing, if able, to do research unpaid, or even pay for another year of education in the interim before applying again. And yet those hyper-competitive PhD programs still pay salaries (in some form) to their students. However, less-competitive programs do not seem to try to compete with other programs for better students by offering higher salaries, as would be expected in a competitive marketplace, even if they receive a windfall of funding. Part of it's a very intense social psychology for sure -- money is not really supposed to be a motivator -- but at the same time you obviously don't want to shut out, or force extra work upon, those who can't simply live on a parental stipend.

This world of top-tier restaurant internships, and many other classy internships, in theory seems like it should work with at least a somewhat similar mindset -- at least at a certain point the interns should be intrinsically qualified and valuable enough to be paid and competed over, else why have interns in the first place?

It kind of reminds me of that famous 19th-century economist's prediction that the most menial worker's wages would always fall to the bare minimum needed to sustain life. Obviously it's not true in an actual labor market, but doesn't it seem to be even worse in the internship market?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18819923
>an entire means to get work experience
It's called getting an education, showing competence in your school performance, and getting an entry-level job (with entry salary and prestige of the company often, but not always commensurate to said school performance).

Unpaid internships encourage a reduction in the number, quality, and pay inentry level positions, and the ubiquity of them in certain fields also makes the educational quality of the internships vary heavily -- and due to the very nature of internships being outside a school, this quality may have zero oversight.

To expand: it is the norm in industry X (civil engineering or culinary arts, say) to have unpaid internships during and/or shortly after graduation. The number of such students seeking internships is so high that companies with even barely a moderate size or prestige attached have zero trouble consistently having many more qualified candidates applying for internships than they could accept even if they wanted. Many long-lived well-managed firms are high quality and see internships as investing in future hires, and take the education of all interns seriously. However, there are many more mediocre companies than these, and they will often defer interns to low-level staff, who may only devote time to actually educating a handful, while, as is *very stereotypical* relegating the *vast majority* to "coffee duty". They can do this because, again, there are usually many more applicants every year than there are positions. And as a company is not paying interns, which is by nature an investment, there is no incentive for retention, promotion, development, etc.

And this is only looking at part of the problem. Unpaid internships are an inherently inefficient, exploitative, uneconomical system.

>A 6 month internship at Noma or the French Laundry is worth much more than a 4 year degree from CIA.
You obviously didn't see a prior thread from last week where OP linked an article where a former recounted her experience at the world's best restaurant -- the first 3 years were spent simply preparing perfect jelly molds into the shape of beetles. (The article was not primarily about that, but that's what we gravitated to.)

As I detailed, an unpaid internship often isn't worth shit except for a few students, often selected not by their merit but by the luck of the motivation of whichever lowest-level manager is tasked to supervise them. Because the company makes zero financial investment, they have no incentive to oversee the training interns (unless they specifically have an internship-to-career-develop program in place, or their upper management sees education and economic development in general as a long-term investment strategy.).

To take an example from engineering, I know for a fact there are companies who have as an informal policy to make those in their first year of internship just to copies and coffee, such that only those who return for a second year (thus "proving company loyalty" or some shit? What did they do to earn loyalty? I guess you're just proving loyalty to whoever offers you another internship in spite of shitty grades, or whoever promises steady employment in an area you want to live) get to do actual developmental work.

In part this is facilitated by universities competing to get exclusive internship slots for students at big-name companies, but for the most part it wouldn't be possible if at the end of the day the internships were not unpaid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813328
Take a basic lean bread recipe. 5/3 flour to water. For 20oz of flour, use 2tsp salt, 1/2tsp yeast, and 1oz olive oil(don't buy it at the grocery store, grocery store oil is adulterated and rancid, regardless of what the bottle says).

Literally just mix this all together into a dough ball, then need it until the dough is smooth and you can stretch part of it thin enough light passes through.

Then portion it into however many pizzas you are making, and ball it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZxNbL5XB7w

Then shove each dough ball in an oiled, sealed container that's big enough to allow it to expand, then shove those containers in the fridge for 48 hours.

Come back, let them warm up enough to work with, and then stretch them out. The dough should be quite thin, 1/3 an inch, with a bit more on the edges.

kneading high hydration dough by hand is a waste of time. it will form a strong gluten network by itself over a period of several hours (google autolysis). all you had to do was wait - you could have simply tossed it in the refrigerator overnight - but your impatience and inexperience got the best of you. posts.name: Anonymous

>>18813932
5 minutes by hand is approximately nothing. I knead my pasta dough for around 10 minutes and pasta dough builds gluten very quickly. for a pizza dough you're looking at 30-60 minutes of hand kneading depending on exactly how wet your dough is, what type of flour you are using, and what additions you're using.
>>18813940
yeah he used a mixer with a dough hook. if you don't have a machine to do the kneading then you're better off just letting the gluten build up naturally through autolysis. wet dough responds very slowly to kneading, you could easily spend an hour by hand to get the level of gluten development he got in just a few minutes on the machine, or you could just give it a few folds every hour for a few hours and get the same result with a lot less work.

Experts (who also have made pizza in home ovens) have advised to use a high hydration dough to compensate for the longer cooking time that dough requires when cooking in a home ovens compared to the much higher heat of restaurant pizza ovens.

>>18814073
Why would you want it to rise before putting it in the freezer like it's the oven? There's absolutely no point to that. It's better to freeze an unrisen dough. Not only does it take up less room in the freezer but any air bubbles will collapse in the freezer anyway due to negative thermal expansion. When you freeze anything you should have it sealed in an airtight bag and press out any air that you can.

posts.com:
I've had good luck with my pizza's recently. I use this recipe...

3 cups of flour (2 white 1 wheat or all white)
3 tsp yeast (standard red star stuff you can get in most grocery stores.
Optional: a tbsp or two of sugar
1-2 cups of HOT HOT, but not boiling, water

First: You'll need a baking stone in the oven.

Methodology, flour and yeast in bowl, mix / fluff (you could also just sift). Add one cup of water mix throughout with your hand until fully absorbed. Start adding small amounts of water and repeat the mixing until you get large clumps that are not sticky to the touch. Knead until all flour in incorporated and the dough is slightly sticky. Leave it alone for 20 minutes. Come back and turn dough into ball (the one you see all the pro chefs do on youtube). Then cover in a dusting of flour and bag the bowl or put a lid on it.

Now you wait at least one hour, but preferably an afternoon or so before rolling it out and putting toppings on it.

To cook it; turn the oven on 30-60 minutes before the pizza goes in and turn it on high. Like 500 F. Top pizza, put in for 5 minutes, turn and check on cheese / crust, cook for another 4-5 minutes and take out.

>>18813328
>teach me how to make a good pizza dough
For an 18" crust :
1 US cup of water
Yeast (1 tbsp or so)
Olive oil (1/4 cup or less)
Salt (1 tbsp or less)
Flour

Mix all this together. You'll need enough flour to get the dough just sticky, but not to much. The other measurements are up to taste, really. I always eyeball it.
Kneed - you should have learned this from your mother. Or at school. Watch a YT if you dunno how.
Cover with olive oil, let it rest. A long slow rest at low temp (cook room for 6 hours) will give you a better dough the a short fast rest a higher temp.

Then you will grease your pan and spread out the dough. Or flour a counter top and roll out your dough.

If you want to get fancy, make a pre-ferment : 1 cup flour, 1 cup water, yeast. You mix all this up the night before and let the yeast have fun over night. Add in the oil, salt and rest of the flour the next morning and let it rise all day.

A wetter (aka stickier) dough will make a better crust but will be harder to kneed if you are doing it by hand.

everybody kneads the shit out of their dough but they're doing it wrong so they're just adding extra work for shittier dough

Just mix the ingredients until combined then let sit for 10-15 min and come back and do a few cross folds every 10-15 min afterward for 4-6 time and even the stickiest dough's will be manageable and have much better
>https://youtu.be/6JQm2n4aVZctexture/crumb

picrel is my pizza dough recipe + i oil the bowl that its proofing in so it doesn't stick and i can do the cross folds

#1.mix salt into flour
#2.make dent in flour and add yeast and water, let sit a few min to hydrate yeast
#3.stir until it starts to come together then add oil
#4 stir until combined and the flour is pulling off the sides
#5. Let it rest 15min (covered)
#6. cross fold a few times every 15min for 5 to 7 times (also add some oil to the bowl at this point)
#let it proof on the counter (covered) for 4 up to 12 hours (you'll need a very large bowl with a lid that snaps on tightly )

>>18818753
Shake your pizza as you build it.
Put ample corn meal or wheat on the peel, put your crust on it
Shake it so it slides freely
Put your sauce on
Shake it so it slides freely
Put toppings on, shake it so it slides freely

If at any point it doesnt slide freely, lift up the crust and use a paper towel under it to remove moisture, and then shake it some more.

It should slide like its on ice skates while sitting on your pizza peel.
Make sure you take the sliding into account when topping the pizza, because its going to get launched. Less cheese and toppings you drop the better

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What do you buy that's going bad before you can use it? Fresh vegetables last a long time when refrigerated, and they're easily the thing I waste the most when I forget to make something or get lazy about it. It can take some thought but try to plan multiple meals around an ingredient that'll go bad quickly, or get comfortable with eating leftovers for a few days. Depending on what you're making you can also freeze leftovers or get creative with them. For example, if I grill chicken breast I'll eat it hot and fresh for one meal and then carve it up and use it on salads and wraps throughout the week.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I want this, but the side burger would get cold and gross pretty quick by the time I would need to use it.
You could install some heat wiring on the interior, but then you'll get sweaty and uncomfortable on that side.
Making it close on top and be insulated could help, but would probably cause sogginess without any ventilation, and ventilation would defeat the insulation.
You could insulate it with the wires and create a simple exhaust system with a small fan, but it would be a bit awkward if you had to sit in a quiet lobby or work meeting while slowly blowing hot burger air throughout the room.
Is the ideal burger holster actually impossible due to thermodynamics?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you cook every meal and/or know how to "keep" food, this wouldn't be a problem. Before I had three mouths to feed, I still never had problems like that.
Buy meat. Freeze meat in single servings. Thaw one when you want a steak or chicken thigh or pork rib or lambchop or burger or prawns.
Celery and carrots keep practically forever. Onions and potatoes, too, so long as you keep them away from each other. They inexplicably go off more quickly than they would otherwise if put near one another.
Leafy veg goes off more quickly, true, but you should be eating leafy greens daily anyway, so biy them and use them up before they go off. Blanch some spinach for your instant noodle. Stir fry some yu choi with garlic and oyster sauce. Make kale and lentils into a soup. Toss your spring mix lettuce with a vinaigrette for a salad. Whatever. Just eat your greens.
Cucumbers, generally, will go off quickly so if you buy them in larger quantities than just one at a time, learn ways to keep them longer. For example, slice and salt them then squeeze of excess moisture, rinse of all salinity and squeeze dry with kitchen paper. Now, you can make it into a salad with keeps for over a week. Alternately, just juice them. I make cucumber lemonade from time to time. Normal lemonade is lemon juice + water and sugar, yeah? I swap out the water for cuke juice. It gives it a great flavour and the green colour is nice.
Buy in season fruit and, like the meat, freeze it in single serving sizes (after pitting, if necessary). I actually still do this one because we love smoothies. Just grab two servings of fruit, 150g plain full fat yoghurt, 100ml water and sugar to taste (or none at all, if you prefer) and blitz smooth.
Etc etc etc
It's not hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820844
Real vanilla is split or perforated vanilla pods steeped in alcohol, usually some milder 40% spirit like white rum or vodka, but sometimes whiskey, brandy or everclear/alcool.
The lemon bottles are usually reconstituted from concentrate, usually with extra citric acid and sodium/calcium citrate to stabilize them.
Real maple syrup is sugar maple sap that's been boiled down to a syrup. I forget what the grades mean, but there's a thick and a thin one.
"Real liquid smoke" and liquid smoke are usually fairly similar. Some will use a single type of wood, like mesquite or hickory, and maintain a more consistent 700-ish F while burning the wood to cut down on more acrid compounds like creosote. Some just use a generic hardwood and try to keep between 650 and 750F. Either way, the wood gets burned in a sealed kiln, the smoke is basically alembic'd over to a second sealed vessel with water (sometimes with a small percentage of neutral grain spirit for better absorption) and allowed to condense and basically drip into it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18821348
Growing koji isn't necessarily difficult if you have a good setup, but if you're doing large amounts there is potential to fuck it up. A handful of small details need to be understood as well.

For the koji you do steamed rice + koji spores at 95ish f and close to 90%+ humidity. The rice must be close to perfectly steamed and each grain needs to be unclumped from every other grain. You have to carefully monitor the temperature of the growing koji if you're doing large batches because it will produce too much heat and go to spore, which ruins the batch. You stir the koji rice to cool it down.

Apparently you continually add more steamed rice to the fermentation as well.


It sounds like you have almost enough to rig something up for a good first try. You need good rice or it won't be worth it. Lots and lots of little details and experientially based decisions to make good sake. Only one place to start if you want it!

If you decide to give it a go you should make a thread it would be cool to see your setup.

>>18821171

Can't say for a pro kitchen, but for a home cook? absolutely not.

All you need to do is before you start cooking, put 500ml of water in an electric kettle. Once you finished cooking, start the kettle and at the same time let the pan cool. By the time the water is boiling, the delta between the 100c water and pan will have closed enough that there is no chance of warping. Pour the boiling water right into the pan, then put it back on the heat at the lowest setting for a a minute or two, and everything comes right off, no warping, no wasting ingredients.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My best friend of 20 years died of esophageal cancer about four years ago, leaving behind a wife and three daughters. It's a tough place to be as most folks don't survive it.

What you want is something high in fat, carbs and protein. Weight gain shakes are pretty reliable. If he doesn't like sweet then well blended legume dishes like pea soup, real home-made baked beans or cassoulet are the way to go.
If he can cope with sweet, things like pavlova and peanut butter brownies are ideal.

Good luck anon. It's shit watching someone you consider to be a brother wither and die while you can do nothing to help. My heart goes out to you and I pray your friend has a better outcome than mine.

Be patient with him
I had serious throat damage and scarring which made it extremely hard to eat, coupled with the doctor giving me a strict diet due to allergies.

I lost 100lbs in one year, people said I looked like a meth head or that I was on the verge of dying.
When its hard to eat, its really really hard to eat. And its really hard to find things that are worth eating.

Not to mention chemo is going to suppress appetite too, so you have a double whammy.
Try to be understanding, because nobody gave me any understanding at all. And I know its way worse with cancer. Its not just as simple as forcing yourself to eat.

>>18818923
>Where do I start bros?
Cooking is a bad hobby if you are depressed because you are forced to eat for sustenance. You will put pressure on yourself to cook a lot, and you wont always be able to do so. You will have to eat generic meals and will feel guilty about it, when you are tired and dont want to cook it will eat you up inside. Its a negative feedback loop.

You want to keep your mind busy, make yourself some healthy meals, but start a new hobby altogether to take up your time. If you can cook, you can build something with your hands.

I welcome you to the friendliest and most helpful board (most of the time) on the site.
>>>/diy/

posts.com:
Hey /ck/ been interested in making tonkotsu from scratch so we’re gonna try it soon. Never made ramen from scratch before. Anyone familiar with the process, can you add any tips or tricks to make it better?
>broth
~3 lb pig feet
Piece of pork fat
Cover with water 2 inches above feet
Boil for 10 min, skim scum, remove from water, rinse, add back to clean pot with water
Roast aromatics, green onion, 2-3 knobs ginger, large yellow onion, several cloves garlic, add to pot
Bring to just over simmer (rolling but not boiling) for 12 hours, stir occasionally
Add water every so often to avoid it reducing too much

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Chashu
Large piece pork belly, skin off (optional)
Trim fat, roll, truss
Aromatics: 1 bunch green onions, cut into segments, 2-3 in knob ginger, sliced, 4-5 cloves garlic
Add 1/2 cup sake, 1/2 Shaoxing wine, 3/4 mirin, 1/2 soy, little bit sugar, water to cover
Simmer in 300 degree oven for 3-4 hrs, rotate halfway throufh
Roast under broiler before serving to crispen

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Put split trotters in pot of water.
Bring to the boil.
Off the heat.
Let sit a short bit.
Drain.
Rinse trotters and wash pot.
Put trotters back in pot, add various aromatics, top off with water, bring to the boil, reduce to maintain a simmer and cook, skimming scum as it forms, until thick and milky white, adding water from a boiling kettle every now and again as necessary.
Literally all ther is to it. Did it last week, actually. We just finished up the last bit of it yersterday. btw, I use 1kg of split trotters per litre of water, which seems like a lot, but that's how I've seen it done so that's how I do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Tare
In sesame oil, add dry anchovies, brown
Deglaze with shoyu and mirin, add bonito flakes, sake optional, simmer, strain, refrigerate
Other additions: dried kombu, dried shiitake
>Toppings
Sliced green onions
Shiitake, enoki, and/or wood ear mushrooms
Bamboo
Nori
>Soft boiled egg
Shock with ice water after cooking
Marinade in pork braising liquid
OR eq parts soy/mirin and water, 1:4 soy/mirin:water

Not making my own noodles, will just buy fresh ones
Final assembly: add couple spoonfulls of tare, spoon in broth, boil noodles, add to broth, top with marinated egg, sliced scallions, mushrooms, sheet of nori, chili oil, and chashu

posts.com:
What's the best way to store home baked bread?

Whenever I wrap it in plastic wrap the crust loses its crispness but if I don't wrap it tight it gets stale so fast. Should I buy those paper bags they store them in at the grocery store? Plastic bags? Or would one of these fabric canvas kind of bags be best?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820309
make less bread so you eat it before it goes off

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820309
Slice it and freeze it after it cools. I shit you not, once you thaw it it's 99% as good as the first day you baked it, where as homemade bread the next day sitting on the counter is only 65% as good as the first day

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820309
slice, ziplock bag , and freeze.
thaw bred slices overnight in the fridge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820309
Freeze small loaves, thaw as needed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
personally, I bake no boil bagels.
I eat one a day. I slice them vertically, so I have a bunch of little pieces of bread that I use for eating chili.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Maybe vacuum it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820309
If you don't want to freeze it you could wrap it in a clean kitchen towel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Keep it uncovered (or in a paper bag) for the first day and enjoy the fleeting crispness, and then put the remainder in plastic and just embrace the soft crust for the rest of the week.

Alternatively make portion sized pieces of bread, store in plastic in the fridge and then rebake when you want one. This will crisp the crust back up and reverse any staling. I do this in an air-fryer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820377

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820436
crusts are stupid. if you want a crust, toast it later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820309
Add a little rye (~10%) to your dough and it will greatly slow down drying and staling, rye has enzymes which help prevent starch recrystallization which is also a major cause of staling. you can also use about 10% tangzon which will also greatly slow down drying and staling.

>>18810603
Okay so for a 25l wash I am using 6 small tins of Lyle's black strap molasses, 2kg Demerara and 1kg of muscvado.
If I run it through my pot still after foreshots and heads I cut down to about 50ish% and redistill everything after that.
With the reflux it comes out 93-96% first pass... The major difference in taste is coming from oak but that's subjective I guess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18810815
One of my friends is doing his first rum and chose to do 100% molasses with yeast nutrient. It has been cold so fermentation has been a bit slow even with a heating belt. Should be fun to see how it turns out.
Done some really nice plum brandy that has this sweet and creamy taste to it. The good stuff was from about 60%-45%abv, 30% abv was bad smelling, so it was tossed and then down at 10% some fruity aromas showed up. The blended cuts came out right at 50%. Fun process and a good excuse to drink a little in the afternoon hah.

posts.com:
Okay I had the rums. Here is Jap rum tasting notes.

Smell:
Vanilla, carmelly oak almost bourbon like, but with less char.

Taste:
A little spicy, unique smooth molasses kind of flavor, limited to no funk, possibly some earthy kind of flavors. Sherry like finish.

Very good stuff. Worth the price. Quite complex once diluted down from the 62.1% will look at reviews of the other casks for sale and pic a second and maybe third.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
24 yr Grenada rum bottle 229/336

Vanilla cake, caramel, cedar, old books, nutty, maybe cinnamon as well

Herbal, subtle and refined flavors, minty, well integrated oak, subtle tropical funk, jordan almonds.

Really really nice, complex, refined, delicious. Yeah, probably worth the price. This one was quite challenging to pick apart the flavor and aroma. Pretty much every sip tasted different.

Because it is very rare, unique, and made superbly well.

They use a special sugar called kokuto sugar to make the rum. The sugar is made by a very slow boil of sugar cane juice and it retains a lot of the molasses.

Honestly, for 100 bucks there's only a handful of other rums that would be as good value.


If you are interested in seeing why these rums are awesome.

posts.com:
>>18802593
It and Flor de Cana are fantastic rums. Most of the time, when you add aging, go for it. One of my most favorites is Barbancourt, though hard to find.

Rum, unlike some rare exceptions do not grow their own sugarcane. Some of them are not distilled and aged in the same places either. So, just go by your own tastes. One of the more popular spiced rums is just artifical flavors (Kraken on the label). If it tastes good and you like it, just drink it how you enjoy it. The craft nature and specialness is not going to be found out of say like 6 brands. Rum is just not hard to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18819718
Rum (raw sugarcane and its fermentation) is very difficult to do right. Depending on variety of sugar, location, humidity etc.

Don't follow the herd, big brands or fads, especially the cocktail/brunch ones. And you'll discover a universe similar to that of great cigars.

I don't add any vinegar. A proper lacto ferment will provide sufficient acidicity. For future reference, if you're looking for a dish that serves the same purpose: Feijoada à Transmontana - red (or black) bean stew with tons of pork, cabbage, carrots, spicy sausage, garlic, onion, cumin, black pepper, paprika and a bit of tomato paste. Buy the cheap cuts of pork with gelatin and bone and salt them a day in advance.
I found this recipe in english: https://www.196flavors.com/portugal-feijoada-transmontana/
Adapt it to your needs.

>>18810272
>What Japanese dish can you also make a big batch of and enjoy all week
Enjoy your food poisoning after 2 days. I hope you use a freezer for "eating all week" of the same damn thing.

For batch cooking japanese food, I'd buy some wrappers or learn the recipe for hot water dough, and stuff some dumplings. Pot stickers are easy mode with a food processor + pork loin + bag of superfood slaw mix + everything from your japanese food condiment pantry such as sesame oil, soy, chili paste, green onions, ginger, water chestnuts, mushrooms.

Frozen steam-in-bag brown rice can make fast dinner prep to go alongside reheated terikaki chicken or beef skewers. Broil on a 2nd glaze of sauce when reheating under the broiler. Cold Asahi with edamame with sea salt is my favorite appetizer when doing pot stickers.

A large batch idea is a big bowl of rich stock for shabu shabu. or else taiwanese version of ramen pork stock.

Just Bento and Just One website recipes are nice for idea inspirations. Yaki onigiri is freezer friendly and heated to order when you recrisp it.

>>18815072
>been using a moka pot for a while.
never wash it with soap,
if it is new you're supposed to run it with just water once and then 3 times with coffee that you'll discard this will season the thing and avoid funky tastes,
use the right grind size for moka and don't press the coffee in the thingy,
fill with hot water until right under the valve, put the coffee in the thing, assemble it ant put it on the stove on mid-low, once it fills about mid way with coffee turn off the heat, right the it starts gurgling pour everything out, afterwards disassemble the whole thing and rinse with water, dry it with a rag and that's it.
If you do it that way and still taste metal discard your chinesium pot and buy a real one.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18810809
>his gayness is too much recently
In what way?

The only thing that made me consider not watching him (besides going back and watching his first two episodes) was that episode which was entirely a paid promotion for a new Disney movie, from beginning to end, including the "history" (completely unrelated to the cuisine, only related to the plot of the film). In fairness he did say at the beginning that Disney asked him to do an episode about this and he agreed because he enjoyed working there, but that's very different from saying at the beginning, "This is a paid promotion." Tbf he's far from the only person to do this. (Freakonomics Radio did a paid (secondary) episode about how much the coauthor liked his Cadillac, also without any clear warning anywhere that it was a paid promotion, for example. Even if you genuinely like the company and product, even if you liked it before you started broadcasting, your TOS for the platform almost always say you have to explicitly announce a paid promotion).

Even in the olden days of TV advertising when TV hosts would themselves make the pitches, it was usually (not always) clear when there was a break from programming to advertising. But as annoying as ad jingles and subliminal messages and the like are, at least modern TV promo ads are almost completely segregated from the content (with important exceptions, which is why I'm using the word 'promo' operatively). I think a reckoning will come when streaming content will have to make this change as well.

>>18807527
There was a decent yt series that only ran a couple episodes, can't remember the name, but the gimmick was that they had three spinners off random ingredients and the chef would have to come up with a meal showcasing whatever three the spinner landed on. The main feature was during the (edited) cooking there were two voice-only commentators giving "live" sports-talk-like commentary, and they actually were really talented (way more so than the chef) -- in addition to having good comedy they had good natural chemistry. So despite the chef being the same in the first episodes and being pretty mediocre, the production quality was good, and of course the commentary was solid, so I actually really liked it. I imagine though, since the commentary track would have to be scripted, that it was a shitload of work to produce and if it wasn't an early hit the comedians probably would have just moved to other projects.

The final cute gimmick they had was their closing scene was the chef saying goodbye while at the sink scrubbing all the pots and pans he used.

He always says he's an amateur and is learning by doing (which often is needed for old recipes anyway) and taking advice from his redditers -- significantly, he's taking and citing that he's receiving help from people on history, language, and cooking.

Most good TV hosts are relative amateurs at the subject matter they may be presenting, because they, like Miller, are instead professionally trained at public entertaining. The difference is that Miller does a frankly astonishingly professional job at citing his sources (for a non-academic/technical youtuber) and shows an impressive amount of deference to often-missed details like quality of sources when it comes to his interpretation of evidence. And then I just find his comic timing really good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813869
>All of his historical knowledge sounds like it's listed straight off wikipedia.
It's not. (Especially not the Mesoamerican history, since the Wikipedia coverage on that is absolute shit.) Cooking history in general is pretty poorly covered on Wikipedia, with not much rigor -- he'd have to, and clearly does, cross-check every citation and every uncited assertion -- I only wish he'd also edit the page as he did so, but then people would later legit accuse him of doing exactly as you claim (even though the article edit histories could be audited I suppose -- he'd be doing all the video research weeks or months in advance though, so it'd be hard to do in some cases).

Additionally, he also is able to enlist (or even pay?) reddit fans to translate old sources for him. I edit WP history and sometimes I'd really love for a superpower like this -- just being able to call upon a loyal reddit army to reliably translate Medieval X into correct context would be sweet.

posts.name: Cookie baker
posts.com:
Hey frens, OP from "cookies from scratch" thread here >>18811946 (https://boards.4channel.org/ck/thread/18811946)

Some anon responded to a request for the recipe and just wanted to clarify that was not me, and that was not the recipe I used.

Cookie from picture is from the same batch. This time I added a couple of chocolate chunks on the top so they can caramelize and it also makes it look nicer. I also just received my rack so they'll be able to crisp nicely. I gave cookies to my family and they all loved them, even my picky mom who hates most cookies.

Recipe in the first comment:

posts.name: Cookie baker
posts.com:
-1 block of Plugra extra creamy unsalted butter (227 g) Kerrygold unsalted also works!
-100 g cane sugar
-70 g dark brown sugar
-2 large eggs plus 1 yolk
-1 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
-2 3oz bars of Endangered Species milk chocolate bars (48% cocoa), chopped into pieces.
-330g All Purpose flour
-1/2 tsp baking soda
-1/4 tsp baking powder
-1 1/4 tsp salt

1. Add room temperature butter (about to 65 F- 70 F) and sugars to stand mixer bowl. Using the paddle attachment, cream for 4-5 minutes on medium high. About halfway through, scrape the sides and bottom of the bowl to ensure everything is mixed properly.
2. Add in eggs + yolk and vanilla and cream on high for another 1 minutes (pausing to scrape down the sides of the bowl halfway through).
3. Add the flour, baking soda, baking powder and salt, and mix on low for 30 seconds.
4. Add the chopped chocolate to the mixture, reserving about 1/3 of a cup for the topping. Gently fold the rest into the mixture until well distributed.
5. Using an ice cream scoop (not exactly sure of the size, but it's the most common one), scoop cookies onto a parchment lined tray, dropping a couple of the reserved chocolate chunks into the bottom of the scooper before scooping each cookie. Refrigerate for 4-12 hours.
6. Place an oven rack in the middle and preheat the oven to 350F for about 20 minutes prior to adding the cookies. Place the cookies on the parchment lined tray(s) you will use. I do 3-4 cookies per tray since these are LARGE cookies and need space to spread out. Bake for about 13-14 minutes.
7. Take the cookies out and leave them to cool on the tray for about a minute. Using a spatula, move the cookies to a cooling rack. Once they are a bit more solid, they are ready to eat! :D

Enjoy!

posts.name: Cookie baker
posts.com: Oh I forgot to mention that I take them out of the fridge about 15 minutes before adding to the oven. I press the dough down to ensure they spread evenly. If I don't do this, the cookies will be very bloated and the edges will burn before the cookie is fully cooked. Just learned this yesterday!

Personally, I wouldn't rely on getting all the minerals from whole wheat bread. It is not sourdough/fermented and therefore still has most of the anti-nutrients in it.
Just an overview of this:
https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/anti-nutrients/
Depending on the eggs and cheese, you may or may not be getting enough vitamin A. The vitamin A content in butter and eggs varies.
Vitamin D is also hit or miss.

The iron content is already low according to the number you provided and is better absorbed by vitamin C.
Since vitamin C is not heat stable, I doubt you are absorbing large amounts of it in your diet.

Is the bread fortified with B1? If not, I would worry about you getting beriberi.

Most water soluble vitamins are not heat stable, so I literally mean that most of these vitamins are probably not present. All B vitamins (except B12, B12 should be adequate in eggs and cheese).
Vitamin C

The National Institute of Health claims you need about twice your 0.8 grams of Omega 3.

The effect of phytochemicals is also still controversial and probably important in the human body.

My conclusion: for a few months it's a good idea, but after a few years you'll probably have problems. Iron is stored, the body can cope with less vitamins in the short term. But not in the long term.

1. Buy jasmine rice
2. Wash the rice until the water isn't totally cloudy
3. Bring 1.5x the rice's weight in water to boil in a pot
4. Pinch of salt in the water
5. Add rice to water
6. Bring rice and water to a boil again
7. Turn it down to low heat and leave covered for 12 minutes
8. Take it off the heat and leave for 5 or 10 minutes
9. Eat it

They are "jaffa" for the orange flavor. The Isreali's invented the drip irrigation that allowed orchards in the desert climate, aka orange groves.
There is a raspberry jam cake, as well as orange.

To me, a cookie should be crisper, so these are more akin to like a moist Little Debbie cake, like without the moistness. They are slightly similar to a black and white cookie, which is also a sponge cake, not a cookie. They're okay in small doses, infrequently. Ehh. The best british cookie is probably the Carr's lemon icing filled ginger thins. They're like half gingersnap, half oatmeal, and sharply gingery with the lemony tang.
